Miles Sound System SDK 6.1c

Miles 2D-based M3D Preferences

Discussion

The Miles 2D-based providers (Fast 2D and Dolby Surround) publish several settings to control environmental reverb effects. Reverb can provide a lot of "feel" to a room, so this is a great option for fast 3D audio.

Note that setting the room types on the software provider is very expensive CPU-wise! You should use the AIL_set_3D_sample_effects_level function to turn off room effects on most samples when running on a software provider. On the Miles 2D providers, each sample with room effects costs about 7% on a P5/200 (3% on a Pentium II).

The easiest way to determine if you are using a Miles 2D-based provider is to query the "Reverb time" attribute. If this query returns a value other than -1.0, then you know that you are running under a Miles 2D-based provider.

Note that you must have the Reverb3.FLT filter available for these preferences to have any effect.

The five current Miles 2D sample-level preferences are:

"Environment selection": this preference allows you to set the reverb's room style. The room styles are same as the EAX 1 provider. You should generally use the AIL_set_3D_room_type function instead of this preference to set the room type for compatibility with other 3D providers. This preference does let you set room type on a sample by sample basis, though.

"Effect volume": this preference specifies the amount of reverb to apply from 0.0F (no reverb) to 1.0F (maximum reverb). You should generally use the AIL_set_3D_sample_effects_level function instead of this preference to set the reverb level for compatibility with other 3D providers. This preference accepts a 32-bit float (F32).

"Reverb time": this preference specifies the approximate time in seconds for the reflection to die out. This preference accepts a 32-bit float (F32) and can range from 0.0 to 8000.0 milliseconds.

"Predelay time": this preference specifies the approximate time in seconds for the reflection to die out. This preference accepts a 32-bit float (F32) and can range from 0.0 to 250.0 milliseconds.

"Damping": this preference specifies the high-frequency roll off of the room. This preference accepts a 32-bit float (F32) and can range from 20.0 to 20000.0 Hz.

"Reverb quality": this preference specifies whether the reverb is performed in stereo or mono mode. Stereo doubles the CPU requirement (from 7% per sample to 14% on a P5/200), so it is disabled by default. This preference accepts a 32-bit integer (S32) - zero for mono, one for stereo.


Group: 3D Digital Audio Services
Related Functions: AIL_set_3D_room_type, AIL_set_3D_sample_effects_level
